skill.name: competitor-alternatives
skill.description: When the user wants to create competitor comparison or alternative pages for SEO and sales enablement. Also use when the user mentions 'alternative page,' 'vs page,' 'competitor comparison,' 'comparison page,' '[Product] vs [Product],' '[Product] alternative,' or 'competitive landing pages.' Covers four formats: singular alternative, plural alternatives, you vs competitor, and competitor vs competitor. Emphasizes deep research, modular content architecture, and varied section types beyond feature tables.
skill.summary: Create competitor comparison and alternative pages for SEO and sales enablement with four page formats and modular content architecture.
skill.author: coreyhaines31

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The SKILL.md file contains only documentation, templates, and examples. The 'external_commands' detections are markdown code formatting (backticks) around URL patterns and template placeholders, not Ruby/shell command execution. No executable code exists in this skill.

content.value_statement: Creating effective competitor comparison and alternative pages requires deep research, strategic positioning, and honest differentiation. This skill provides templates, structures, and frameworks for building SEO-optimized comparison content that builds trust through transparency.
actual_capabilities: Create four types of competitor comparison pages: singular alternatives, plural alternatives, direct vs pages, and competitor vs competitor pages
Build modular content architecture with centralized competitor data for consistent updates across all pages
Structure comparison pages with proven section templates including TL;DR summaries, feature comparisons, pricing tables, and migration guides
Research and document competitor strengths, weaknesses, pricing, and positioning for accurate comparisons
Optimize comparison pages for SEO with keyword targeting, internal linking strategies, and FAQ schema markup
Write honest, balanced comparisons that acknowledge competitor strengths while positioning your product effectively
limitations: Does not provide real-time competitor pricing or feature data - requires user to supply current information
Does not access external websites or APIs to research competitors - relies on user-provided research
Does not generate visual assets or design mockups for comparison pages
Does not validate SEO performance or track keyword rankings

prompt_templates.title: Basic Alternative Page
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a [Competitor] alternative page. My product is [Your Product]. Key differentiators are: [list 3-4 key differences]. Competitor weaknesses to highlight: [list]. Target audience: [description]. Include sections: TL;DR summary, feature comparison, pricing comparison, and migration path.

prompt_templates.title: Detailed VS Page
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a comprehensive [Your Product] vs [Competitor] comparison page. For [Competitor]: strengths are [list], weaknesses are [list], pricing is [details]. For [Your Product]: we excel at [list], we struggle with [honest limitation]. Target keywords: [list]. Include honest assessment of who each is best for.
prompt_templates.scenario: Direct product comparison with balanced positioning

prompt_templates.title: Alternatives Roundup Page
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a best [Competitor] alternatives page. My product is [Your Product]. Include 5-7 real alternatives. For each competitor, summarize their key strength and ideal use case. Structure: introduction, evaluation criteria, comparison table, detailed breakdowns by alternative, and recommendation by use case.

prompt_templates.title: Competitor Index Architecture
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a competitor comparison index page structure. We have [N] direct competitors. Create an index that links to: individual alternative pages, vs comparison pages, and competitor vs competitor pages. Include best practices for internal linking, sorting strategy, and maintaining fresh content.
prompt_templates.scenario: Organizing multiple comparison pages into a hub

output_examples.input: Create a Notion alternative page. Our product is Coda. Differentiaters: docs-first with advanced tables, better for operational workflows. Competitor weaknesses: limited automations, slow with large databases.
output_examples.output:
## TL;DR: Notion Alternative

Notion excels at flexible, all-in-one workspaces but struggles with performance at scale and limited automations. Coda is built for docs-first teams needing powerful tables and operational workflows. Choose Notion for flexible personal workspaces. Choose Coda for operational teams who need structured data.

## Feature Comparison

### Documents
**Notion**: Beautiful block-based editor, excellent for rich content creation.
**Coda**: Doc-native with tables embedded, better for data-heavy documentation.

### Databases
**Notion**: Flexible but can slow down with thousands of records.
**Coda**: Built on a powerful table engine, handles large data efficiently.

### Automations
**Notion**: Limited automation capabilities compared to dedicated tools.
**Coda**: Native automations with triggers and actions built-in.

Choose Notion if you need extreme flexibility. Choose Coda if structured data and operations are priorities.

output_examples.input: Write a HubSpot vs Mailchimp comparison page for a B2B SaaS context.
output_examples.output:
## HubSpot vs Mailchimp: Marketing Platform Comparison

### TL;DR

Mailchimp is an excellent choice for small businesses seeking simple email marketing. HubSpot offers a full platform with CRM, automation, and sales tools. Mailchimp is best for email-focused teams. HubSpot is best for companies wanting integrated marketing, sales, and service capabilities.

### Pricing

| | HubSpot | Mailchimp |
|---|---|---|
| Free tier | Limited CRM only | 500 contacts |
| Starter | $20/mo | $20/mo |
| Professional | $800/mo | $350/mo |
| Enterprise | Custom | Custom |

### Which to Choose

**Choose Mailchimp if**: You need straightforward email marketing, have under 10,000 contacts, and don't require CRM integration.

**Choose HubSpot if**: You want integrated marketing automation, need CRM capabilities, and can invest in a full platform approach.

best_practices: Be honest about competitor strengths - readers will verify claims and distrust one-sided comparisons
Centralize competitor data in one place so updates propagate to all comparison pages automatically
Include real alternatives beyond your product on plural alternatives pages to build trust with researchers
anti_patterns: Do not use generic feature checklists - explain why differences matter with specific use cases
Do not oversimplify complex products into checkmarks - provide context for each feature comparison
Do not ignore migration complexity - honest migration notes build credibility with evaluators

faq.question: How many alternatives should I include on a plural alternatives page?
faq.answer: Include 5-7 real alternatives including your product. Being genuinely helpful by showing multiple options builds trust and improves SEO performance for comparison searches.

faq.question: Should I acknowledge competitor strengths on comparison pages?
faq.answer: Yes, acknowledging competitor strengths builds trust with readers who are likely comparing multiple options. Honest assessments position your product more credibly.

faq.question: How often should I update competitor comparison pages?
faq.answer: Verify pricing quarterly and check for major feature changes. Update competitor data when you learn about significant changes from customers or announcements.

faq.question: What makes a good TL;DR summary for comparison pages?
faq.answer: A good TL;DR captures the key difference in 2-3 sentences, clearly states who each product is best for, and helps scanners quickly understand the comparison.

faq.question: How do I choose which competitors to create pages for?
faq.answer: Prioritize competitors with high search volume for competitor terms, competitors that prospects frequently mention during evaluations, and competitors where you can honestly differentiate.

faq.question: Should I create competitor vs competitor pages that do not include my product?
faq.answer: Yes, these pages capture search traffic for competitor terms, position your brand as knowledgeable, and introduce your product to qualified audiences researching alternatives.
